description.narrative: Support for Implementing the Policy Plan for Legal Protection and Human Rights, and Anti-Corruption
capital of a political entity
Human rights affairs
Support to the Parliament of Suriname

This project aims to strengthen the National Assembly of Suriname in carrying out its core functions and responsibilities, based upon a comprehensive approach to parliamentary development. The project will focus on 8 areas: legislative function, oversight function, representative function of parliament, Secretariat and staff services, parliamentary strengthening instruments, international relations, gender equality and ICT strengthening of Parliament. The project will be running for 4 years.

General and technical understanding of REDD+ by all relevant stakeholders. Level of support to REDD readiness efforts disaggregated by stakeholders and right holders. Capacity of Suriname to integrate gender dimension and ensure women participation in all readiness efforts.

comment.narrative: The level of understanding is limited to the information provided into the R-PP, which has not been widely shared yet. The level of support is limited so far. The R-PP considers gender dimension, but attention to gender issues is generally limited.

Building capacity of the PMU, Major Group Collective and the IP to enable effective participation in the REDD+ process Continued support the development og local community radio broadcast, network and coverage Ensuring the Framework for Grievance and Redress Mechanism is understood, start of a information sessions with PB,and MCG Ensuring an integrated follow-up and implementation of the project document
Communication plan has been designed draft engagement plan and strategy contracts with Redd+ Assistants Collectieve (RAC) Mid Term review

description.narrative: Strengthening national capacities of Suriname for the elaboration of the national REDD+ strategy and the design of its implementation framework
capital of a political entity

Collective capacity to produce quality deliverables Level of attention toward poverty reduction, human rights based approach and gender consideration in the REDD+ strategy National degree of understanding and consensus on drivers of deforestation

comment.narrative: There is moderate and recent national capacity and experience in strategic planning (OD) and environmental and social impact assessment (NIMOS), and no experience in the case of REDD+ The R-PP offers a first overview of background situation, but remains incomplete for robust REDD+ strategic planning and impact assessment A draft REDD+ option framework has been formulated during the R-PP, and general ESSP was carried out by UNDP as part of the PRODOC No national experience neither in SESA nor in ESMF There are some experiences related to environmental impact assessments in Suriname but not related to system of information on social and environmental safeguards Some elements of the future REDD+ strategy detailed in the RPP. Coherence between OD2012-2016 and REDD+ is weak Precedent of Guyana, which is probably not directly replicable in Suriname Limited contribution of Suriname into international REDD+ process so far No dialogue and no international commitment on international support for phases 2 and 3 of REDD+ in Suriname

work continued on the SESA reporting and ESFM implementation work continued on preparation of the Land Tenure and Land Rights start preparations and discussion with governmental and private sector in the National REDD+ strategy start the preparations The driver of deforstration study is being undertake
the drivers of deforestation study finalized

Background reports policy, legal and institutional challenges for REDD+ implementation are being prepared Work started to prepare the REDD+ national strategy which will be endorsed by the Council of Ministers; work started for Polls rank awareness of REDD+ by political leader. Work started to draft a National development plan post-2016 fully builds on REDD+. Work started to draft a report on Land Tenure and Land Rigths Work continued to draft a Report on Corruption and Risk Analysis. Work continued to prepare a Report on Innovative Economic Opportunitied . Work continued to prepare the framework of REDD+ options

final draftBackground reports policy, legal and institutional challenges for REDD+ implementation draft of the REDD+ national strategy and start of awareness to the Council of Ministers; work conitnued for Polls rank awareness of REDD+ by political leader. Final report National development plan post-2016 fully builds on REDD+. Draft a report on Land Tenure and Land Rigths Final Report on Corruption and Risk Analysis. Draft Report on Innovative Economic Opportunitied . Work continued to prepare the framework of REDD+ options

description.narrative: A comprehensive implementation framework is designed and related instruments are built progressively
capital of a political entity
Collective capacity to produce quality deliverables Level of attention toward poverty reduction, human rights based approach and gender consideration in the REDD+ implementation framework and tools

comment.narrative: Apart from a few projects related to forest monitoring and delayed processes to design an environmental law and a climate compatible development strategy, there are scarce capacities in place to design a full implementation framework and related instruments for REDD+ implementation. Some historical data on deforestation and degradation are scattered and incomplete. Limited capacity to design scenarios through spatial modelling No experience and capacity in designing reference level. Existing collaboration with Guyana on related topics. Forests are punctually monitored in a weakly coordinated and harmonized manner. Methods and data quality does not match international standards and lacks continuous run up. Legislative branch has moderate awareness of REDD+, little understanding of potential legal implications, and complex reforms are expected to be required to implement REDD+ in Suriname The institutional and financial arrangements needs for REDD+ implementation are roughly assessed

continue institutional capacity strengthening at SBB for the implementation og REDD+ activities related to NFMS, NFI. and forest REL/RL conitnue the information sharing to other govenmental agencies and private sector related to the NFMS and NFI start to update the national forest definitation start with the geoportal on data related to forest monitring start the Drivers of Deforestation study and the PAM
Drivers of Deforstration study Geoprotal completed

Continue South-South collaboration, add capacity building component to the ongoing studies, support capacity building within other institutions Start the discussion for the FREL/ FRL in parallel with the NS - FREL/FRL nationally presented and agreed upon Continue updating the Land Monitorings System. Prepare to insert data on degradation in the Land Monitorings System

Continue South-South collaboration, add capacity building component to the ongoing studies, support capacity building within other institutions: study visitis to Guyana and Brasil were undertaken The discussion for the FREL/ FRL in parallel with the NS was held final draft FREL/FRL updated the Land Monitorings System. Data on degradation in the Land Monitorings System updated

title.narrative: Final Suriname GCCA Prodoc 4 April 2016 clean update 19 April 2016
International Consultant ? Preparation of the ?SURINAME Global Climate Change Alliance PROJECT

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDPs results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPs projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

The preparation of Suriname INDC is now starting in the month September under coordination of NIMOS, with hiring of international and local consultant as well as support from CI Suriname, UNDP and World Resource Institute.
capital of a political entity
Knowledge and understanding of climate change effects and of opportunities or ways to cope with negative effects are enhanced.
capital of a political entity

Frequency and accuracy of climate related information and analysis provided by MSD, WLA and other climate change related institutions. Availability of a nationwide water resource (hydrological) model. Number of climate change adaptation measures developed for the agricultural sector.

comment.narrative: The existing hydrological and meteorological network stations managed by MDS and WLA are presently only a broad network, mostly developed for weather (rain and river flood) forecasting purposes though is far from accommodating the variable of local climate over the whole country. Data analysis from WLA is provided on quarterly basis with 80% coverage of coastal area region. Hydrological models in Suriname are too strategic and poorly detailed to help advice at the local level and subsequently do not permit to develop appropriate sectorial or local adaptation strategies. Datasets on hydrology and meteorology are present, but considerable effort is likely to be needed to collate, compile and digitize this work into a format that is useable for modelling purposes. No data is available for the interior regions. MDS provides data analysis (depending on the type of station) for the coastal regions on a daily and monthly basis and less frequented for the interior regions.No national level adaptation measures or policies are available.

-Finalize systems design, equipment requirements and technical specifications for the expansion of the existing MDS hydro-met network. -Coverage MDS increases up to 20% for the interior and WLA has an increased coverage of 10 % for the coastal area. Initialize digitization of historic data of MDS . -At least twonational/regional knowledge sharing events

-Equipment requirements determined for expansion of MDS and WLA hydro-met network with support from Caribbean Institute for Meteorology and Hydrology . Installation of 5 (more than 10%increase) of WLA hydro-measuring stations 4 in major rivers and 1 in front of the coast.in collaboration with the Anton de Kom University of Suriname. -Work plan for Digitization of historic hard copy MDS data finalized and approved. -Three national knowledge sharing events organized

Issuance and implementation of at least 3 grants under the Climate Change Grant Facility Procurement and installation of new equipment MDS & WLA Training of MDS and WLA staff Upgrading National Water management plans

Q1 Results 5 New water measuring stations of the hydro department installed Selection of 5 Proposals under Grant Facility Water Governance Seminar and training organised in collaboration with Ministry of Natural resources and Water Forum Suriname Q2 Initiation of 4 projects under Grant facility Procurement of Greenhouse for farmers Weg naar Zee Knowledge sharing with partners on financial management funding Advertisement procurement for Hydro-Met Equipment for increase in Coverage Hydro-met network Q3 Training in Disaster Risk management and Development of 01 District Disaster Plan Inception of mapping and resilience building in Community in Upper Suriname Q4 Purchase and storage of Hydro met equipment Procurement of installation of Hydromet Equipment (5AWL, 2 AWS, 4 raingauges , 1 Hydrolab, water quality) Installation of Irrigationsystem and protective structures for training of farmers Coastal area Weg naar Zee in Climate-Smart Agriculture Training in Disaster Risk management and Development of 02 District Disaster Plans

description.narrative: Essential tools and structures for sustainable management, focused on conservation of mangrove ecosystems, are in place.
capital of a political entity

% of mangrove ecosystems under newly established management / legal instruments that allow sustainable use and or limit any use and targeted and enforceable protection tools (e.g.: no take zones). % of Mangrove managed by a set of norms and guidelines agreed with and coordinated between key Ministries and Departments for the future management of mangroves.

comment.narrative: Nearly the entire coastline of Suriname falls within the countrys system of protected areas. Only a section near the eastern coast border and the highly urbanized central coastal area surrounding Paramaribo are excluded. Still, effective protection is hampered by the lack of proper management structures, outdated management plans and insufficiently organised and equipped patrolling teams. In spite of the extensive system of protected areas, mangrove trees themselves do not benefit from a legal protection status.

-25% of the countries mangroves are covered by legal instruments for essential planning tools to ensure their long term sustainable management by end of year three. -At least 80% of the countrys mangroves are managed through a set of formalized guidelines by end of year two. -Integrated Coastal Zone management based on GEF Environmental Mainstreaming project and the GCCA+ ICZM Project -A Mangrove Biodiversity Monitoring Program is developed and functioning

Basic patrolling equipment made available for increase in monitoring and patrolling in coastal MUMA's Management Effectiveness tracking tool made more user-friendly for the staff and stakeholders of Coastal MUMA's and coastal protected areas METT protected area management through translation in Dutch. A Mangrove Biodiversity Monitoring Program is developed and Initiated through inclusion of Mangrove monitoring in existing National Forest monitoring Initiative in collaboration with Foundation for Forest Management and Production Control, Nature conservation Division, Centre for Agricultural research and National Herbarium
Development and Implementation of Mangrove Strategy Training of NCD Staff At least 2 Knowledge Sharing events Mangrove Biodiversity monitoring programme up and running

Q1 results: Three days a week, twice per day transmission to of awareness to at least 50% population in radio programme Improved patrolling of the NCD wardens through improved transport equipment and planning Mangrove Strategy Technical workshop organised Q2 Development Action plan for Mangrove Strategy Annual Donor report completed Joint Awareness Activity in Eastern Rural Suriname on Climate Change Impact increase in transmissions of Radio Programme on mangrove awareness Repairs/Restoration on Building Mangrove Education Center Coronie completed Q3 Stakeholder's assessment of Eco services in coastal communities in 4 districts Inception of stakeholder consultation for Economic Valuation in Bigi Pan MUMA (Multi Use Management Area) Event on Gender and Synergy in Climate Change Actions in Suriname Q4 Increase of radio programme transmission frequency to 5 days a week, twice per day transmission to at least 50% population Knowledge Sharing event on Climate Change Adaptation Capacity building of the Nature Conservation Division for Patrolling and Monitoring in Coastal MUMA's Dissemination of results on Eco-Services in Communities in coastal communities in 4 Districts Planning and Preparation for Mangrove monitoring System within the National Forest inventory

description.narrative: Mainstreaming global environment commitments for effective national environmental management.
The IRRF is UNDPs results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPs projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

Strengthen key government structures, as well as mechanisms for the civil society sector, to improve the institutional framework set up to implement the Rio Conventions and to deliver global environmental benefits.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Degree to which environmental data/information is available and accessible to government and civil society. Existence of an agreed roadmap towards the development of a legislative and institutional framework for environmental management at national level.

comment.narrative: The following information is available disparately but not accessible to end-users in a comprehensive way: national biodiversity information under NBINS; development indicators under DEVINFO; statistical information under ABSinfo; water-related data under SWRIS; land registration and land information system under GLIS; forestry information under NFI, conservation data by NARENA. There is not an agreed roadmap towards the development of a legislative and institutional framework for environmental management at the national level.

Set up project management team. Host inception workshop. Hosting of Environment Statistic Report 2016 Agreement and broad buy in elements and roadmap of the Knowledge Platform. Scoping report on roadmap for change for Improved environmental governance
Project management team realized. Environment Statistic report 2016 launch Visitor Exit Survey training carried out. Second Climate Outlook Forum on climate relevant data for the different sectors.

Hosting inception workshop. Finalization of Inception Report. Agreement and broad buy in elements and road map of the Knowledge Platform. Scoping report on roadmap for change for Improved environmental governance. Support revision to draft Environmental law and subsidiary regulations. Environmental Atlas.

The inception workshop was held during Q1, 2017. The Inception Report is finalized and available. Discussions on the road map of the Knowledge Platform have taken place, with agreement to build on and link with the Gonini platform that is established by the REDD+ program. The technical support for revision of the draft Environmental law and subsidiary regulations was contracted and assignment started.

Agreement and broad buy in elements and road map of the Knowledge Platform with agreement to build on and link with the Gonini platform. Scoping report on roadmap for change for Improved environmental governance. Environmental Atlas available. The road map of the Knowledge Platform completed. The technical support for revision of the draft Environmental law and subsidiary regulations was contracted and assignment started. Sustainable Financing options strategy technically endorsed and available.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance to the Ministry of Regional Develop

description.narrative: Technical Assistance to the Ministry of Regional Development

title.narrative: Technical Assistance to the Ministry of Regional Development

description.narrative: Strengthening of the institutional capacity of the Ministry of Regional Development to deliver efficient and targeted services to marginalized population across Suriname with particular emphasis on vulnerable and deprived communities in the hinterland. This will be achieved through support for the establishment of a strong national volunteerism programme, the Suricorps Foundation for Development; addressing specific needs for basic services of selected vulnerable and deprived hinterland communities; and local communities are empowered to have a voice in development processes through localizing
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: 1. Consultant report tested the feasibility of a national volunteer programme and institute, Suricorps; and the status of development of the different districts in Suriname reflected in the Human Development Atlas. 2. MICS Report 2010, and Suriname MDG Progress Report 2014. 3. SIDS country report Suriname

Implementation of Localizing SDGs addressing local authorities and communities, with IEC materials specifically designed for the various groups in society on the basis of language, and age group, among others. Knowledge and lessons learned on Localising SDGs were also shared internationally , including Caribbean Region and Belgium.
Installation of the water harvesting system including training of members of the local community in installing and maintenance of a water harvesting system.

The International UNV, with expertise in institutional building and volunteerism, was assigned to provide technical assistance in establishing institutional structure for the National Volunteerism Programme. Review meetings and plan of action presented by the IUNV to the leadership of the Ministry of Regional Development and Inventory of possible involvement of volunteers within the ministry completed; design of a sustainable institutional structure of the National Volunteerism Organisation; and adjusted bylaws presented. Pilot recruitment and assignment of volunteers tested.
Rainwater harvesting system (pilot site Ovia Olo) installation in progress and technical training for the community for the installation and maintenance of the water harvesting completed. Rainwater system and community engagement approached is being extended to other community by the Ministry of Regional Development with funding from the JCCCP project.

1. Localising SDGs continued targeting communities in the hinterland and rural coast, and school youth. 2. Official launch of the Rain Water Harvesting System (RWHS) at Ovia Olo with presentation of certificates to the community members who have completed the training on the installation and maintenance of RWHS.

Localizing SDGs activities continued with outreach and community based data intake on the status of development covering local authorities and communities of three (3) villages of the Upper Suriname River region (hinterland) and the villages/plantations at the right banks of the Commewijne River (rural coastal communities). The awareness activities also included in and out of school youth, women, traditional leaders, fishers etc. A special awareness session was also held with the school youth of Moengo, an small town at the most eastern district, involving 6th grades of Moengo and surrounding villages.
RWHS officially launched and certificates for skills training in installation and maintenance of RWHS system presented to community members of Ovia Olo village who successfully completed the training. Majority of the trainees were women.

Development of an Integrated Rural Development Plan with pilot initiatives identified. The Integral Rural Interventions concept offers to its participants solutions in food safety and security, individual and collective productive projects, housing and the development of collective social, productive, environmental and cultural assets. It also empowers the communities that participate in the programme, by the development of collective projects and the fostering of participation spaces. Specifically, this initiative will contribute in parts to the achievement of SDG: Goal 1: ends poverty in all its forms everywhere Goal 2: end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture Goal 4 on inclusive and equitable quality education and promotion of life-long learning opportunities for all focuses on eliminating gender disparities in education and ensuring equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable. Goal 8: to promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all, the international community aims to achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value. Goal 10, which strives to reduce inequality within and among countries by empowering and promoting the social, economic and political inclusion of all.
An Integrated Rural Development Plan for Suriname and at least one pilot activity implemented

- Institutional structure of MCM in place and advising NIMOS and the Office of the President. - National team of Officers at NIMOS and other institutes identified for training in 2017. - Areas with mercury use identified for detailed survey. - 1 missions undertaken.
Project Signed Terms of references finalized

Institutional structure of MCM in place and advising NIMOS and the Office of the President. - National team of Officers at NIMOS and other institutes identified for training in 2017. - Areas with mercury use identified for detailed survey. - 1 missions undertaken.

Some areas with mercury use have been identified for detailed survey. A number of in Field missions have been undertaken. local team for mercury inventory is operational and has started assignment. The procurement for the international support consultant for Mercury inventory is initiated.

description.narrative: Technical Assistance to the Ministry of Home Affairs in the area of Election preparation and mainstreaming gender equality
The IRRF is UNDPs results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPs projects contributed to
Number of new laws or policies to increase women?s participation in decision-making
Number of strengthened laws or policies to increase women?s participation in decision-making
Number of women benefitting from private and/or public measures to support women?s preparedness for leadership and decision-making roles
Institutional Strengthening of the Ministry of Home Affairs and specifically the following sections of the Ministry: the Elections Bureau, the National Gender Bureau and the Communications Department
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

i. Consultant reports and feedback from the Ministry on the level of participation of staff during the sessions and the level of knowledge improvement after ii. Number of sessions to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry staff regarding gender equality iii. Ability of the staff of the Ministry of Home Affairs to conduct capacity strengthening sessions on gender equality for other Ministries/ groups

comment.narrative: i. Suriname has scheduled elections for May 2020 and the Ministry of Home Affairs is largely responsible for preparing and organizing elections. The Ministry however has a serious shortage of staff and a lack of institutional memory in the Elections Bureau, since a crucial number of staff who previously worked at this bureau has been replaced. ii. The Ministry of Home Affairs is mandated to mainstream gender throughout the government and throughout the governments planning processes. The National Gender Bureau has sufficient staff, but these staff do not all have the required capacity to perform their functions. The Gender Bureau is in need of capacity strengthening and requires assistance with implementation of gender mainstreaming plans throughout the government mechanism

For 2016 the following targets have been set: i. Capacity strengthening training sessions regarding elections and election organization for selected staff of the Ministry ii. Study tour/ observation of US elections and participation in USEP Conference iii. Gender capacity building activities for students and specifically for men

The following results have been achieved in 2016 One of the goals as set out in the IWP and the work plan was to create enhanced awareness on the importance of gender equality and the office has done a fairly good job at implementing activities to reach this output. UNDP collaborated with the Ministry of Home Affairs to ensure awareness was created amongst a varying number of target groups. Sessions for 50 civil servants on gender concepts such as gender basics, gender roles and abuse against women ensured that these implementers now have enhanced competencies to train their colleagues and counterparts. 500 secondary school students (ages 12 - 16) participated in learning followed by a school quiz testing in a fun and creative manner the knowledge they gained on gender concepts for children. The third group consisted of 53 University students who participated in a tailor made course on on the topics of gender equality, gender roles and violence against women.
A group of representatives went on mission to the USA where they participated in the 2016 US Election Programme and the 7th Global Elections Conference. The group consisting of 6 officials of various sections of the Ministry of Home Affairs returned to Suriname with more in-depth knowledge on the organization of elections and also made some pertinent recommendations to the Minister of Home Affairs in this regard (early voting specifically for people who are working in the interior, political party financing, accessibility of voting booths/ polling stations and legislation for privacy on person information.

For 2017 the following targets have been set: i. Capacity strengthening training sessions regarding elections and election organization for selected staff of the Ministry ii. Conducting a number of focus group sessions with stakeholders to gather information and evidence to design the National Gender Equality plan iii. National Gender Equality plan drafted and ready for approval by the various parties iv. Final draft of a full project document ready for approval by the Government and UNDP

Throughout 2017 the CO collaborated with several partners to advocate for the importance of integrating gender throughout all areas of work. With the Ministry of Home Affairs (the ministry responsible for gender mainstreaming) work was done aimed at building awareness amongst specific target groups. Approximately 100 Civil servants [[B.1.1.a.1], and 60 secondary school students now have an enhanced understanding of basic gender concepts. Building on the work done on gender equality in 2016, a joint session was hosted with UNFPA for a number of high level Ministry officials to launch the UNDP/UNWOMEN regional publication on violence against women. A masculinity programme was done specifically to build the capacity of 30 men in the understanding of gender equality concepts and the role they can play. A year-long course designed by UNDP and the Ministry of Home Affairs focused on strengthening the staff of the Ministry to organize and prepare for elections. The CO extended technical assistance to the aforementioned Ministry for a process of evaluation and re-design of the Bureau for Gender Affairs, with the most important output being a way forward regarding the National Gender Equality plan.
The National Gender Equality plan is in draft. The full prodoc will be initiated in 2018
